poem:
Title: "Gavel's Whisper"

Court queues coil like dreams deferred,
Trump's trial, a daisy chain of expectations.
Now it's 5:05, no web-born bird,
A verdict teetering on lost connections.

One minute to history's drumbeat echo,
Yet, the hands on the clock do not know
How to stitch the threads of tomorrow
When internet's thread is lost in sorrow.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Court queues, no internet: I covered Trump’s trial – this is what it was like It was 5.06pm Thursday. Donald Trump, the first president in US history to face a criminal trial, was one minute from hearing the verdict in his momentous case. History, or at least the first draft, was about to be written. The problem? The people in court reporting said history didn’t have any internet. Related: Donald Trump had lots of negative". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
